title: Human Tour Guides for Mixed Reality: A Comparison of Capture and Display Techniques
description:
Virtual environments can be complex and overwhelming. In addition, when wearing a bulky head-mounted display one easily feels isolated from the real world. 
 For my Master's thesis I investigated how humanoid embodied tour guides could be created to accompany and guide users in a Mixed Reality environment.
context: Masters Thesis at TU Dresden towards M.Sc. Computer Science and Media

detailsSections.title: Introduction
detailsSections.text: Working with UE4 and Meta's Quest Pro, I created a Mixed Reality art gallery prototype. I used the prototype as context to test three different representations of guides with varying degrees of visual realism. To simplify the creation process I looked at ways of recording real tour guides to transfer their behavioral realism onto the virtual guides. For example, I explored the Quest's body and face tracking to animate a MetaHuman. Through user testing, I then compared the representations towards Social Presence and overall user acceptance.

detailsSections.title: Background and Aims
detailsSections.text: Virtual environments can be complex and overwhelming. In addition, when wearing a bulky head-mounted display one easily feels isolated from the real world. For my Master's thesis I investigated how humanoid embodied tour guides could be created to accompany and guide users in a Mixed Reality environment. Furthermore, I was interested in how the guide could efficiently explain content by applying Joint Attention Mechanisms such as Pointing and Gaze direction supported by verbal terms. I aimed to increase Social Presence to provide a trustworthy company, mental support and increase the level of comfort.

detailsSections.title: The Guide's Characteristics
detailsSections.text: State-of-the-Art guidance varies in terms of visual realism, level of embodiment and how they integrate into the immersive environment (Spatial Accuracy). While I explicitly sought to compare different levels of visual realism, the characteristics of the representations I compared cover all degrees for each characteristic trait.

detailsSections.title: Recording Techniques
detailsSections.text: As I ended up comparing one video based guide and two synthetic guides I needed different approaches for recording.

detailsSections.title: Recording the Video Guide
detailsSections.text: For the video guide I recorded a video using an iPad. The position of the iPad was tracked throughout the video recording to derivate the guide's position in space.

detailsSections.title: Recording the Synthetic Guides
detailsSections.text: I explored different techniques to extract motion data from a single view image. They did not suffice to simultaneously track position in space, accurate hand gestures and facial expressions. I ended up using the Quest Pro's motion tracking capabilities to record hands, face and position of the guide.

detailsSections.title: Mixed Reality Prototype
detailsSections.text: The MR Prototype I developed has two different modes: An admin Mode for recording a guided tour and a visitor mode to participate in a guided tour.

detailsSections.title: Interaction
detailsSections.text: I provided the user with a personal menu. Whenever a hand is rotated towards the face with all fingers stretched, the menu appears. This gesture is more comfortable and reliable than a 'looking-at-a-watch' gesture. The user does then interact with the menu by tapping the buttons.

detailsSections.title: User Testing
detailsSections.text: I ran user tests to compare the guides. The graphic shows the testing procedure consisting of 3 steps.

title: Traffic Stream: Waiting Times
description: For a semester project, in a group of 2 we implemented an interactive prototype with React, TypeScript, deck.gl and mapbox to visualize traffic data on a map. title: Shopping Knob
description: The goal was to develop a prototype to support a healthier lifestyle.
context: University project for the course User Interface Engineering; group size: 4

detailsSections.title: Brainstorming
detailsSections.text: We started off with brainstorming to come up with first visions and ideas. Based off of a collection of factors which make up a healthy lifestyle we decided on the reduction of stress. We thought of situations in which we are usually stressed and running back and forth in an overcrowded supermarket to find all items is definitely one of them

detailsSections.title: Analysis Phase
detailsSections.text: The analysis phase consisted of field studies, interviews, stakeholderdiagram, definition of personas and a hierarchical task analysis (see fig.).

detailsSections.title: Design Phase
detailsSections.text:
The design phase comprised Activity Design, Information Design and Interaction Design. For each design phase we summed up the features to rate them towards future implementation. The design phases led us to a storyboard and a paper prototype. 
 We listed problem scenarios and transformed them into activity scenarios to get an idea of how the personas would address their problems as of now. We then put together claims to rate the key features of the activity design. Next, based on the activity design, we listed information design scenarios to find ways to support the activities. Again, a table of claims helped us to rate the information design features.

detailsSections.title: User Testing
detailsSections.text: We ran user tests to find out how our prototype performs. The subjects had to complete a set of tasks and were asked to "think out loud" and answer a questionnaire.

title: Smart Home
description: Setting up a Smart Home to control heating, lighting and multimedia.

detailsSections.title: Background
detailsSections.text: We have a Smart Home at home which isn't as smart as it could be. We have window sensors which are potentially be able to send a signal to the heating thermostats and tell them to switch off when the window is open. But the communication is very unreliable. Moreover, at the moment they make regulating the temperature rather more complicated than easier. We have a dolby surround system which can connect an additional speaker in the kitchen area. However, they always need to be manually connected and disconnected when switch between listening to music and watching TV. We have lighting which can only be fully controlled via a smart phone app. In summary, our smart home relies on a variety of apps and is inaccessible for visitors.

title: Train Together
description: Within 2 weeks, we worked full-time to implement a prototype system to do physical exercises together. The prototype enables the user to ask others to joint a training session via pressing a button. The matrix then displays an execise. LEDs indicate when the exercise starts and ends.
context: University project for the course Physical Computing; group of 3
contribution: brainstorming + development of one of three prototypes

detailsSections.title: Background
detailsSections.text: As due to Covid we were stuck at home, we decided to implement a prototype system to do physical exercises together. In a group of three, each team member created a physical prototype based on an Arduino. The prototypes communicate with each other to provide a way to invite others for syncronized exercising and to suggest an exercise. The button is used to start an exercise session, the display shows an animation of the exercise.

detailsSections.title: Materials
detailsSections.text: We were randomly given a set of components to work with for building our prototype. I had a 8x8 LED Matrix, 3 LEDs and a Photoresistor to work with. I used the photoresistor for going online (when you are up for a training session) and offline (to mute the device when you do not want to exercise). Therefore, you have to take off the head. The LEDs indicate the state with yellow for receiving a training request, green when an exercise is running and red when the exercise is over. Multiple buttons allow to select a body region you want to train. An exercise is randomly suggested under consideration of the chosen body part.

detailsSections.title: 3D model with Fusion
detailsSections.text: I designed a 3D Model for the prototype using Fusion 360. The model incorporates the 8x8 matrix, the buttons for the selection of exercises and the LEDs to indicate the state. The head can be taken off to cover (unmute) or uncover (mute) the photoresistor.

detailsSections.title: Communication
detailsSections.text: In order to enable an exchange between the devices, they connect to the local WLAN and communicate via a shared server using web sockets. For this purpose, a JSON message format was defined to establish a session, respond to a session request and receive an exercise. The prototype switches states based on those requests.
